What's your definition of fiscally conservative? Does it mean support for sufficient taxation to pay the govt bills, or do you use the term as a synonym for govt downsizing and more tax cuts for the rich?

As a good Democrat (and former Congressional nominee, 2008, 2nd District of Missouri) I agree with Obama that letting the tax-cuts of the rich expire (and the experts say there are not enough deductions to accomplish the same thing through limiting them) and using that money to reduce the debt, or for teachers, infrastructure and such stimulus, or to avoid tax increases for the middle-class who spend a higher portion of their income and thus the money would help the economy improve faster, is the sounder fiscal policy.

But the Republicans in the House are dead-set against it to protect their rich Republican friends.

And playing chicken with the fiscal cliff doesn't seem to most to be a good idea.

So will one of those Phi Beta Kappa Mensas on either side of the aisle in DC please suggest that the two sides split the difference and let 1/2 the tax-cuts for the rich expire, and the other half continue for some reasonable period of time, and let's move on to deductions and other issues to avoid the fiscal cliff disaster? Whichever side proposes it first will gain lots of capital (not Bain Capital) with the voters, and woe be unto the other side that opposes such a reasonable and natural compromise, in my opinion.

Bill Haas
St. Louis

@ Brent in Vancouver: "PETE WELLS, is the rhetorical question device throughout the review a meta-statement somehow? Does the annoying adolescent mean-girl sarcasm reflect the poor service and inedible quality of the food? Were you actually too angry or lazy to write NYT quality criticism? Should I be as outraged about this restaurant as a Senator over a super-bowl half-time wardrobe malfunction? Did you expect your readers to click to the next page?"

Yes, perhaps in terms of Strunk 'n' White-type style the review was a bit repetitious, with the rhetorical questions interspersed with messages for the kitchen, and, yes, perhaps it would've been well-served by a modicum of cutting.

But in this case I think the repetition and length serve the piece in communicating the critic's level of outrage; his ongoing shock at just how extremely godawful the place is, particularly in relation to the fame of its namesake and "brand." It's got a rawness to it that I think adds to the humor. It's a kind of diner's cri de coeuer. I say Bravo!

Just saw it this evening which was opening night.  To be sure, this won't win any drama awards, but those that thought it would are clearly confused.  However, this is a super fun farcical comedy with some clever dialog, good staging, and well performed acting.  Cheyenne Jackson as "Mandrew" was definitely the star of the show, and showed that he can do good physical comedy as well as deliver his lines with good timing and intonation.  And of course it was fun to see Henry Winkler, who was also well cast in what I think may have been his broadway debut.  In any event, at 90 minutes without an intermission it's certainly an evening's worth of fun entertainment, and despite what the reviewers and commenters say, it got plenty of laughs and good fun. This is the tack I'm taking at the moment. I have two siblings and 11 cousins who are quite a bit younger than me, and a lot of my friends have kids. I enjoy playing "auntie", and spoiling them as much as I can. My boyfriend also has a teen daughter, who is awesome and whom I'm close to. I'm very glad she enjoys spending time with me, and we have a lot of fun.

I may or may not have my own at some point, but I feel very fortunate to have all these great kids in my life.

We are among those who decided against parenthood.  When the time came to start a family, the two of us together earned about $20,000, and a nanny cost $10,000, according to friends who had one. Obviously, that was a while ago. Over the years, we have had wonderful times with nieces, nephews, students, "self-appointed foster nephews," and various young people who have "adopted" us as surrogate parents.  If, as Hillary Clinton declared, "It takes a village," then we are happily part of that village.  We were never forced to expand our carbon footprint, i.e., to buy a suburban house with its two cars. We have been able to share with two generations of young people visits to the Museum of Natural History, the NY Historical Society, the Met Museum, MoMA, opera, and Broadway, something we never could have done if we'd also been paying their tuition.

It is astounding to realize that in its beginning the "civil war" in Syria was just another case of country entering into an Arab Spring movement. I was so hoping that we would do something, maybe not as involved as we were in Libya, but finding a way to be of some assistance. When you think about the problems Syria's government has caused in Lebanon and Israel, its ties to Iran and its potential to roil the whole region, the thought of doing nothing seemed implausible to me. My entire teen experience was filled with fears of the Viet Nam draft catching up with me. As a result of growing up with that experience I have always been very reluctant to support a US involvement in any conflict. However, to some degree the NATO involvement in Bosnia, but mostly the one in Libya, changed my view of the possibilities of helping countries whose people want to remove a despot and wish to enter into a democratic process, by their definition of course. I was not so much angry at our lack of involvement, as I was dismayed. When I try to talk to people about the war in Syria I am equally dismayed at the lack of understanding of what is happening there. I fear that the longer we wait the higher the likelihood that there will be involvement by extremist elements. That we have done so little on even the humanitarian level is astonishing to me. I think we risk the things we fear most by doing nothing.
